stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream importing Biobak’s new assets (temple gates, rotating apple, Poochy, Shy Guys, spears, foliage) into the latest build, while simultaneously debugging doors, memory usage, lighting and collision. He showcases a newly-written collision routine that removes Mario 64’s quarter-frame randomness and experiments with dynamic per-vertex lighting on a rotating apple. The session is framed as live asset-integration for the Poochy/Basement section of Return to Yoshi’s Island.

development_findings.summary: Kaze finished a new collision routine that forces Mario to stick to sloped platforms consistently, eliminating the vanilla game’s frame-dependent randomness.
development_findings.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

development_findings.summary: He added rubber-banding behaviour to the large rolling egg so it accelerates as the player moves ahead, keeping the chase exciting.
Overworld work is back in sync; one skipped segment was completed off-stream and further overworld tasks resume after the current level is done.
Engine upgrade phase is ‘basically done’; remaining legacy bugs are from older assets becoming incompatible.
development_findings.quote: Fortunately, we're basically done upgrading the engine, so that shouldn't be happening anymore, soon.

development_findings.summary: Memory overflow (8 MB N64 limit) briefly re-appeared; Kaze freed several kilobytes by moving small actor data to the emergency memory pool and plans to remove unused vanilla assets; current ROM is ~60 MB and must stay under 64 MB.
Implemented dynamic per-vertex lighting for the rotating apple so vertex colours and shading coexist; required real-time light-normal computation and matrix transforms.
Temple gate doors needed custom hard-coded movement and wider opening angles; culling radius optimised for performance.
Discoball and split-screen multiplayer are planned but not yet implemented; multiplayer would stack two framebuffers vertically and demand further memory savings.
Kaze noted landing still suffers from sub-frame loss; a full fix would require delta-time physics—currently deferred.
development_findings.quote: This is unsolvable without introducing proper delta-time physics in Mario 64, I believe.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy: eliminate hidden randomness and sub-frame quirks so players never need to learn ‘quarter-frame precision’.
context_findings.quote: I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind.

context_findings.summary: He feels pressured to perform asset work on-stream for transparency, leaving only bug-fixing for off-stream hours.
Personal life nuggets: newborn daughter is babbling; excitement over a repaired robotic lawnmower; wife (Zeina) recently shaved his hair as a joke—recurring humour about ‘abuse’.
Merch store integration with YouTube is delayed; minor frustration voiced.

biobak.summary: Delivered updated models: temple move gates, rotating apple with Yoshi sticker, low-poly Poochy, redesigned Shy Guys, spears, foliage and cloud props; emphasised single-material efficiency and reduced triangle counts.
Actively discussed shader choices, collision placement, and memory impact with Kaze in chat; both agreed on compromises (e.g., CPU-side lighting for apple).

zeina.summary: Earlier Shy Guy models originally came from Zeina; Biobak’s new versions are replacing them.
Sent a draft thumbnail for an upcoming F3 (Fangame Fest) video; Kaze liked it but wants clearer messaging.

key_stories.title: Fixing Slope Randomness
key_stories.summary: Kaze noticed that walking off certain moving platforms could randomly fling Mario or keep him grounded, depending on sub-frame alignment. He rewrote the collision routine so Mario now reliably sticks to slopes.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla Mario 64’s quarter-frame step logic produced unpredictable behaviour.
key_stories.process: Created a near-continuous collision system that eliminates sub-frame dependence and tested it on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Consistent platform behaviour; cornerstone of the new engine.
key_stories.key_quote: You consistently stick here. I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind.

key_stories.title: Rotating Apple Lighting
key_stories.summary: Biobak’s apple needed both vertex colours and believable shading while spinning. N64 hardware lacks per-pixel lighting, so Kaze devised a CPU routine that calculates per-vertex shade each frame and stores it in shade alpha.
key_stories.challenge: Vertex-only lighting looked flat on a rotating object.
key_stories.process: Estimated sphere radius, computed light normals, applied matrix transforms, iterated with live printing, fixed overflow bugs.
key_stories.outcome: Apple now has smooth dynamic shading without extra textures.
key_stories.key_quote: All this just to get some shadows on the stupid apple.

key_stories.title: Memory Pool Crisis
key_stories.summary: Importing new assets pushed the build over the 8 MB RAM limit, causing crashes.
key_stories.process: Identified which actors could live in the emergency pool, moved them, and planned code/asset pruning.
key_stories.outcome: Build runs again; clear action plan to stay under 64 MB ROM and 8 MB RAM.
key_stories.key_quote: We were all over just a couple of kilobytes, so by chucking some random stuff into the emergency pool we freed up enough memory.
